com.ibm.watson.dsm.engine.analysis

Class AnalysisEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ibm.watson.dsm.util.AbstractListenerManager<IEvaluationListener,java.util.List<TupleState>,java.lang.Object,java.lang.Boolean>
      • com.ibm.watson.dsm.engine.AbstractRuleEngine
        • com.ibm.watson.dsm.engine.analysis.AnalysisEngine
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IRuleEngine

    public class AnalysisEngine
extends AbstractRuleEngine
implements IRuleEngine
    Provide a pseudo-RuleEngine that evaluations rules against inputs to produce the set of all possible end tuple states. Typical usage would be something like the following: 
     AnalysisEngine engine = new AnalysisEngine(rulesFile);
 engine.start();
 ...
 //  Set the initial state of the engine 
 ITupleSet tupleSet = ...;
 engine.getTupleStorage().append(engine.getApplicationDescriptor(), tupleSet);
 ...
 // Cause a rule evaluation
 tupleSet = ...;
 engine.addTuples(tupleSet);
 ...
 // Get all the possible states that could have resulted.
 List endStates = engine.getEndStates();
    For a simple set of rules that do NOT use the 'choose' modifier, there will be a single end state of tuples. However, when choose is used in the rules, then there are multiple possible outcomes and that is what this engine tries to capture.
    Author:
    dawood

    • Method Detail

      • evaluateTupleRules

                      ITupleSet... tuples)
                           throws DSMException
        Capture the initial state and given inputs in case we need to recurse on this method via applyChoose(DSMSQLStatement, int, ITupleSet, int, int).
        Overrides:

      • applyChoose

        protected ITupleSet applyChoose(DSMSQLStatement s,
                    int recursiveEvalIndex,
                    ITupleSet tuples,
                    int maxCount,
                    int minCount)
                         throws DSMException
        Overrides the super class to cause recursive evaluations with all possible combinations of tuples implied by the choose request.
        • If this is the first time this statement is being evaluated with the choose, then build the list of all possible tuple combinations.
        • else (if this is not the first time then) get the previously computed list of combinations.
        • Remove the first combination from the list of possible combinations.
        • If there are more entries in the list of possible combinations, then trigger a new top-level evaluation with the same initial state and input tuples. Expect this new evaluation to evaluate and come back to this method and use the next combination in the list.
        • Return the the combination of tuples removed above and let the current evaluation complete.
        Overrides:
        applyChoose in class AbstractRuleEngine
        recursiveEvalIndex - -1 if this is a NOT recursive query, otherwise an index that is unique for each recursive query. This is currently only used by AbstractRuleEngine.applyChoose(DSMSQLStatement, int, ITupleSet, int, int) so that the AnalysisEngine, which overrides that method, can distinguish different calls. The actual value is immaterial except that they must be unique across all recursive calls within a given evaluation request. In addition, the index must be repeatable for the same set of rules.
        Returns:
        never null, a modified set, possibly modifying the input.
        Throws:
        DSMException

      • evaluationComplete

        protected void evaluationComplete()
                           throws DSMException
        Capture the end state of the tuples as one of the N possible outcomes. We only capture the end state if it is not a duplicate of those already captured.
        Specified by:
        evaluationComplete in class AbstractRuleEngine
        Throws:
        DSMException

      • getEndStates

        public java.util.List<TupleState> getEndStates()
        Use this method to retrieve all possible states from a given evaluation request. After requesting an evaluation via evaluateTupleRules(boolean, ITupleSet...), the full set of possible end tuple states will have been calculated.
        Returns:
